thread.title: Watch: Incredible last-lap NASCAR Truck crash
thread.title_full: Watch: Incredible last-lap NASCAR Truck crash

title: Watch: Incredible last-lap NASCAR Truck crash
text:
Last lap NASCAR trucks crash 1:21 NASCAR: 12 trucks involved in wild last-lap crash at Daytona, sending Matt Crafton flipping February 25, 2017 2:55pm by Staff writers Source: FOX SPORTS IN a night of racing at Daytona that featured crash after crash, NASCAR’s Camping World Truck Series saved the biggest Big One for the last lap. 
Already on a Green-White-Chequers two-lap shootout due to a prior crash, the leaders tangled as the field rushed off Turn 2 for the final time in the NextEra Energy Resources 250. 
A hard push in the tailgate sent second-placed Ben Rhodes into race leader Matt Crafton, sending the No. 88 truck backflipping down the track’s backstretch before landing on another truck. 
LIVE stream the NASCAR Daytona 500 LIVE on FOX SPORTS with the Foxtel Sports Pack. Get your free 2-week FOXTEL PLAY trial and start watching in minutes. SIGN UP NOW > 
In all, 12 trucks were involved in some way shape or form with all drivers escaping unscathed including Crafton, who walked away from his battered truck and was cleared of injury at the track’s medical centre. 
The carnage allowed 18-year-old Kaz Grala through for his maiden Truck Series win, becoming the youngest driver to win at Daytona in NASCAR national touring series’ history. Austin Wayne Self (32) passing the flipping Crafton (88). He’d go on to finish 2nd. Source: AP 
Running as the third truck in the line behind Crafton when the crash happened, Grala’s car missed centre-punching Rhodes’ truck by millimetres. 
“There wasn’t any way I was going to lift,” Grala said. 
“I was just going to go low and cross my fingers and close my eyes a little bit. Luckily, it worked out for me. I can’t believe it. This is just so surreal.” 
Austin Wayne Self ended up claiming second, with Chase Briscoe, John Hunter Nemechek and his father, veteran NASCAR driver Joe Nemechek, rounding out the top five. 
The last-lap accident took out many of the top trucks on the night, including defending series champion Johnny Sauter, who had won the event’s first two stages and dominated much of the race. 
The last lap crash put a full-stop on a night that had seen more than its fair share of big ones. 
The first involved 17 trucks, and came as the field came out of the tri-oval to start Lap 2. Austin Cindric (19) hits the wall as Noah Gragson (18) and Ryan Truex (16) collide. Source: AP 
The No. 29 Ford of Chase Briscoe hooked the rear end of the No. 18 Toyota of Noah Gragson, setting off a chain reaction. 
“I was running seventh or eighth at the time and felt like I just got popped from behind by the 29 going through (Turns) 1 and 2. … I had a good time out there for the lap that I got,” Gragson, an 18-year-old driving for Kyle Busch Motorsports, told FOX Sports. 
Another would occur just as the first ‘Stage’ wrapped up. 
As reigning series champion Johnny Sauter crossed the line to take the bonus points, the No. 4 truck of Christopher Bell got airborne. 
he No. 23 GMS Racing Chevrolet of Spencer Gallagher triggered the accident by getting into the back of the No. 7 Toyota of Brett Moffitt, who then clipped Bell’s truck and sent it into a wild, flying spin that took all four wheels off the ground. 
Amazingly, Bell not only landed safely but continued on in the race — before being involved in another multi-truck crash with 29 laps to go. 
A spin from John Hunter Nemechek brought out a caution and set up the final restart with three laps to go. Crafton eventually surged in front of Sauter and they were battling for the lead when the biggest, wildest wreck of a night full of them occurred. 
— With foxsports.com
